review: This is a superhero film, that is both a great movie, and appropriate for my kids! I'd even say it was better than the hit first film! It was hilarious, enjoyable for parents and kids, PG, had great story arcs and characters, and much much more! I will say that you have to rewatch the first one before you see this movie, though!

title: Best movie
review: One of the best movies this year hoping for part 2

title: LOL.
review: Well all I have to say is that this movie is feminism at its finest. This could have been a great sequel but instead it reads... "It's 2018/2019 and everyone is offended so let's produce so some whinny activist doesn't get hurt"

title: An Immensely Solid Sequel that Shines on its Own, As well as being a Fateful continuation of its Predecessor,
review:
Incredibles 2 is a fantastic movie with a very well developed plot and a stellar voice cast. As far as sequels go, it really does shine and is probably one of the best continuation to an animated film I have seen in a very long time. Though he may have been shying away from them for several years, it is clear Brad Bird did not stop thinking about these characters, the love, passion and intrigue in developing them further was felt in this screenplay throughout.

My only issue with the film really is that the villain does not shine half as much as Syndrome, who was one of the highlights of the first Incredibles. While there are brilliant moments, particularly a very tense scene where Elastigirl tries to track their location, the motivations and scheming of the character is quite cliche in terms of superhero movies, and was not nearly as personal or hard hitting as it felt in the original.

The voice cast is all around fantastic and as great as ever, and the new sides we see from the characters in this movie are fascinating, without feeling out of place or forced in any way. The star of the film, for me, is Violet, who is given a spectacular arc that I was always the most invested in, while Jack Jack was also a joy in every scene and a character with so much fun capabilities for writers.

An immensely solid sequel. Despite the difficult challenge this film takes of being a sequel people waited 14 years for, it takes this challenge heads on and manages not to disappoint, The Incredibles 2 is a joy from beginning to end.

Following directly after the events of the first movie, Elastigirl takes up work with an organisation striving to save the protection of superheroes, while Bob stays home with the kids and discovers Jack Jack's superpowers.

title: Very weak as a story and the audio engineering is horrible
review:
We love Pixar and was really excited when this film was mentioned to come out. The long wait turns out to have been not worth it. Voices no longer fit the characters, the story just seems to be rushed and weak and whoever mastered the audio should never work in audio again.
We got this movie on Amazon for rent and we had to blast the audio at 90% to hear some of the story and in other areas 10% would rattle the windowd, very beginner levels in this part of the film; after about half way through the film we were discussing shutting the movie off. Pointless and not worth the time.

title: Mr. Incredible made to look like Mr. Underwhelming
review:
TL;DR pretty good overall but was needlessly politicized and betrayed original portrayal of some of the main characters.

The first film was a groundbreaking animation back in 2004, one that I will always keep going back to: witty dialogue full of one-liners, smooth sequences, a group of heroes rooted in the everyday lives of the (majority of) the audience - and a villain just as iconic. It was, and remains a memorable tour de force in Pixar animation and a stunning achievement in cinema. People everywhere love superheroes for being so different, they are seen as an answer to the world's problems - but Brad Bird showed us that being ordinary: a mother, a father, a friend, son or daughter is equally as extraordinary and equally as important in keeping bad at bay. He showed us that the family in all its parts is worth so much more in its whole - this sequel betrays that beautiful expression. In the original Incredibles movie, Elastigirl and Mr Incredible were equals. They both had strengths and weaknesses, and in the end she ended up saving him. I loved that movie. It was about a loving family and about equal partnership. The sequel abandons that.

After many viewings of the first film, I've asked myself: "does this really even need a sequel? Has everything Brad Bird wanted to say been said?" That's up to you to decide, but the fact that Incredibles 2 is the second highest (nearly the highest) grossing animated film of all time, behind 2013's Frozen, speaks for itself; people believed Brad Bird had more to say and turned up in their droves to hear it.

The anticipated sequel did (eventually) come after a 14-year wait. But was Pixar's 20th feature film up to the coveted "incredible" standard?

Continuing where the last film left off; superheroes are still illegal, and the Parr family is against the ropes trying to find its purpose after it faces mounting legal pressures to hang up the suits for good.

It sounds like a good starting point, but things rapidly take a turn for the worse:

1. It's needlessly politicized: a consistent portrayal of Mr. Incredible as insecure and unstable:

This film shifts the focus away from Mr. Incredible as the centerpiece, not necessarily a bad thing, but a major problem is that it was done in a way that made Mr. Incredible look like a clueless idiot.

"Mr. Underwhelming"

Mr. Incredible was shown as an embittered, incapable father figure that is clearly annoyed (and jealous) that his wife wasn't staying at home and he was out doing the crime-fighting. He was portrayed as too "messy" to be a hero, and as a father even messier; degrading and depressing, this motif contributed nothing to the story and spat on the previous film's legacy, it lacked any comedic nuance.

It was completely out of character for Bob Parr, a character who is known to be selfless, supportive and at no point in the previous film had demonstrated egotistical traits that this film now claims he has. If anything, a cringe-worthy stretch to make Bob look like a bumbling oaf.

Furthermore, the film's third wave feminist influences can be seen clearly early on: "it's not like I don't like strong women... I'm pretty secure, manhood-wise" - an utterly pointless line bizarrely included in an early scene from Violet's crush Tony Rydinger. Why is that line remotely relevant to the wider plot? Out of context social commentary doesn't need to be there, especially not in a family entertainment film aimed at kids. Did Brad Bird sell out?

2. A poor villain that lacked screen-time, charisma, and was nowhere near as engaging as Syndrome.

The villain, while having some iconic attributes, wasn't connected to anything particularly significant or as deeply personal as Syndrome was. The audience was never made to feel the villain's personal plight or raison d'Ãªtre, because of that the villain wasn't engaging, was largely predictable, and failed to earn much (if any) emotional investment.

3. Too much emphasis on the "stay-at-home dad" trope.

Family is core part of the Incredibles, always has been, but the focus was obsessed on the Jack-Jack subplot, the unraveling of his powers and Mr. Incredible's unfunny mental breakdown. All were novelties that wore thin, using precious time where something more original could have been developed (there was plenty of screen-time to do so). Fortunately, the movie wasn't a showreel of old gags and throwbacks, even if returning to Edna (a fan favorite character) was a marketable move for the trailer, it was not a decision that really moved the plot forward.

It gets a 5/10, because it was half of what the first film was. Cinema may be past its prime, politics have seeped into most big-budget productions, this one included.

title: Ignore the nasty reviews and enjoy the ride.
review: This is a great return of this fun super hero family. Giddy over the top action with awesome characters and a good story. These low reviews are clearly left by people that are sad and dead inside with no sense of humour or sense of fun.

title: Really enjoyed this movie
review: This movie was really good would recommend this to anyone

title: Rushed and cheap
review:
Can't believe that something that took 14 years to release felt so rushed and cheap. So disappointed. I know they tried to update the animation with the advances in technology but in doing so they made it feel cheap. It was like watching an episode of Paw Patrol.

The original is one of my favourite movies, animated and otherwise. Great story and decent animation that actually holds up incredibly well.

The story was ok in parts with some decent gags but that was about it. It felt like a mass produced TV series on Cartoon Network, not a Pixar event movie.

My kids thought it was good. I think they laughed at the bits Brad wanted them to. I think most of the problem is that it is aimed squarely at young kids. Not at all ages like many other Pixar classics.

They left the door open for sequel after sequel. Clearly going to follow the money. This felt like the 5th sequel after they licensed some other studio to carry on with it when they couldn't be bothered with it anymore.

title: A good, but not great, sequel.
review:
I love the original Incredibles, it's probably my favorite Pixar movie, or close to it.

The Incredibles 2 hits many of the right notes, but suffers a little bit from sequelitis.

The good: The characters are still lovable and are consistent with their previous movie. The action sequences are great, and there are more of them than in the first film. The animation and visuals are "incredible," and somehow match the aesthetic of the first film while taking full advantage of the 14 years of computer graphics advancements. The comedy is also "pretty good," although some of the best jokes are in the trailer. The graphic design of the film is also stunning- on par with the first film, if not even more polished.

The bad: Feels like a "monster of the week" episode of a TV show more than a movie. The timelessness and gravitas of the first movie don't even come close here, and the philosophy feels a bit more forced and less digestible. The comedy, though generally enjoyable, also isn't quite as polished throughout. There's also a weird flavor to the writing here, like the movie knows it's being watched, and so it's treading a bit too carefully...nothing too detrimental, but I found it harder to relax with the film because of it. Things just didn't feel as natural.

Another thing that might throw some people off, the balance of character use is very different here. It's almost inverted from the first film, so that's good in the sense that it's something new, but some people may be disappointed if their favorite character doesn't really "do much."

Anyway, this is a good film, and a good sequel, but it definitely has flaws. I'm a little saddened that the film didn't match the first one in terms of timelessness and relatability, but to re-visit the Parr family one more time, it was worth it.

title: The Movie Everyone's Been Waiting For
review:
Pixar has been a company that everyone cherishes. From their classics like Toy Story and Monsters Inc., to even their solid attempts at sequels in Monsters University and Finding Dory, their heart is and always has been in the right place. The reason I don't include Cars in this discussion is simply due to the fact that the sequels were only made to make the studio sell more merchandise. I don't fault them for that, because their original content is usually always stellar. The Incredibles was a film that was beloved by the majority of audiences around the world and it left people wondering why a sequel wasn't being made. Incredibles 2 has been long overdue for fans and there was almost too much hype to really live up to it for some. Personally, although I don't think this sequel surpasses the original in any way, it sure does live up to the hype in my opinion. Here's why I believe this movie delivered on all fronts.

Picking up immediately after the events of the first film, this film can easily be viewed as an extension of the original, rather than a sequel. The seamless transition between films was flawless in my opinion. The world still believes that superheroes are a potential danger to the world, so Helen is taken away to help prove their innocence and to reinstate their relevance once again. This ends up leaving Bob with a task he really doesn't want all that much; taking care of the kids. Having to deal with his baby (Jack-Jack) having very special abilities, this causes a lot of stress in his life, but also a lot of laughs for the audience. Helen's storyline is very solid and makes for some great additions in terms of storytelling, but this is where the film doesn't quite get to the standards set by the first movie.

Yes, Bob taking care of the kids is cute, Dash and Violet (his older kids) both have amazing times to shine is incredible (pun intended), and Jack-Jack's misadventures are show-stealing moments of hilarity, but I found myself a little tied down by the drama involving Helen. Her storyline exists in order to further the plot of the villain, which is completely fine, especially in a film made for a younger audience, but there were times that felt slightly predictable and bogged down the film a little. That being said, the pacing and cutting back and forth between these two storylines are really the only complaints I had about this movie. I personally think the first movie is near-perfect, so this is why I can't quite say I loved it as much as its predecessor.

Where Incredibles 2 does make things a little more interesting is in its surprises and heart. There is plenty of action/espionage throughout the movie to keep fans entertained, but the backbone of the movie is reversing everyone's role in comparison with the first movie and it really did add a layer that I felt authentic, which I was expecting to feel forced. The pacing in the middle of the movie is saved by a fantastic conclusion that had me grinning from ear to ear. Some people may find this movie to be a slightly slower burn than the energetic pacing of the first, but that's simply because the story required it.

Incredibles 2 is a fantastic sequel and easily one of the best follow-ups that Pixar has ever done (excluding the Toy Story sequels obviously). Personally, I think this movie was well worth the wait. It went in a few directions that I wasn't expecting it to, its themes are very relevant to today's climate and adults will definitely see where that comes into play, and the score by Michael Giacchino leaps off the screen. Very well written and directed by Brad Bird (who also helmed the original), this movie is the definition of a film that warrants its existence and proves that the people who were demanding a sequel were doing the right thing throughout the years. Incredibles 2 may not become as beloved as its predecessor, but it's still a fantastically well-done film nonetheless.

title: Impressed!
review:
I was quite a bit nervous that this movie would not live up to it's 14-year hype, but am pleased to say it completely did! 
All of the characters are the same, with fun humor, and and overall great story. I'm probably stating the obvious here, but the original, per usual, is still superior. This movie had a bit of a less spy-eske tone, but I can't really downgrade it for that. 
Some of the more memorable side characters did appear less that I had really hoped, like Edna, who was barely in the movie unfortunately, but the movie did add a seemingly larger scale of superheros in the metropolis. 
HOWEVER, 
I really do hope that these films are not turned into a franchise, as I really feel like we could easily be over-saturated with them. 
I think this film left the series off pretty well, and am nearly praying that Disney will not try to franchise this one. I don't want another Star Wars situation here. 
Please do check this movie out!

title: An extremely fun and fascinating watch
review: This movie is so great in terms of all the basis a movie needs to be great. Fantastic animation as expected, great voice acting, a compelling and smart story, heartwarming messages, and necessary character development. The most surprising out of these for me was definitely the compelling story. Although the story for the first Incredibles movie was noticeably dark, this movie seemed to double down on that factor, and it only benefited from it. The villain, when revealed, is extremely believable in their motives and reasoning for their evil actions. I honestly expected there to be an abundance of pandering children's jokes in this movie, but I should have known that as with the first Incredibles movie, there was a very minimal amount of this. The humor was very smart for the most part and quite literally the only issue I had with the movie was that some of the jokes and gags the movie tried to pull off just didn't work for me. I was able to mostly forgive the movie for this though, because these scenes were very few and spread out. I commend the director for working on this movie until he felt that it was as good as the original movie if not better, and I personally would say it is even better than the first. More than anything, this movie is extremely thrilling (which I didn't expect), heartwarming, compelling in terms of story, and just overall a fantastic Summer movie and a family movie. The action scenes in this movie were also filmed extremely well in my opinion and deserve to be recognized for it. This was a great movie and I highly recommend to see it on the biggest screen you can find.

title: Did not like
review: I would've walked out but took my granddaughter so stopped for her but when it finished she said it was boring too.

title: Incredibles2 - Mrs Incredible!
review:
'Pixar' fantasy adventure in the style of 'Mission Impossible'

Takes place immediately after where the original finishes. Sexual equality is a major theme, this instalment focuses on the 'mother' character who is assigned missions to complete while the 'father' character stays at home to take care of the kids.

As superheroes are illegal, the 'mother' hero wears a bodycam to record the action and raise public awareness. This is a high action and very colourful animated film. Great for a young audience, adults might find a little boring.

title: Absolutely Incredible!
review: This movie was totally worth the 14 year wait! Very nostalgic since the first Incredibles movie was my first movie I saw in theatres. Hell its even better than some live action superhero movies.

title: I know
review: I know it deserves better rating but for me cartoon shouldn't get more than 5

title: Not an incredibles movie!
review: Not only is the tone completely different, but the characters personalities are fundamentally different! This is not the incredibles i know and i will forever hate this movie.

title: Short story, long film!
review:
Having young sons, it's safe to say that Pixar's Incredibles was a staple movie that delivered many of the cartoon giant's trademarks; compelling storyline, social messages and a very balanced sense of humour that strikes a chord across all levels. This set the bar reasonably high for the arrival of the very long awaited sequel. 
Before it hit the screens, I wanted to love it. The trailers were reassuringly witty and there was hope that the cliffhanger from the first film would bring much more of the same. 
So what happened? Well it's with disappointment that I gave too say Pixar probably misfired on this very rare occasion. 
The plot was reasonably weak, literally dragged over the finish line. The "twist" was transparent and yet it took almost the while film to unravel. 
It feels like Pixar's script writers were absent when the comedy elements were forged and so most of the jokes were already broadcast in the trailers. 
The whole plot failed to muster anything more than mediocre pace as it meandered to a conclusion, leaving an empty feeling where the laughter and love of the latest Pixar production were meant to be. 
Small moments of mercy from Baby Jack-Jack offered just a glimpse of how the film should have felt, but this brand is far greater than a single character and so for the first time in the history of Pixar, I felt like I needed to jump out abs help push the movie to the final credits to put it out of its misery.

title: Disapointing
review:
Its more like a 2e first movie, alternate 1e movie. 
All of the politics does make it worse. 
It could be so mutch more... 2bad

title: Weak villain, weak plot, but carried the charm of the first.
review: How much I wanted to enjoy this film cannot be stated enough. After all, we have waited 14 years for this film, only to discover that they should waited 5 more years to at least give us a better villain. I'm a sucker for multiple entries so I wouldn't be surprised if they did a third, but if it's anything like this then I hope they don't even bother. The laughs and action were plenty, particularly in regards to Edna and Jack Jack, but that aside we get an average super hero movie that truly should have been better.

title: A Masterpiece!

And wouldn't you know, this evil villain is Pixar's first female villain! That's quite an achievement, in my opinion. The other characters are interesting, too. The story is very great. The dialogue is good, and the acting is entertaining. This is a classic that's sure to entertain you.

review: And by staggering, I mean that I am at a loss for word to impart just how unfunny this show is. why even bother with animation? Every ounce of fun, or humor has been wrung out of this. To make sure that no one in any way could be offended; to even imagine the thought of it. Why are these kids talking like adults? Like the most colorless, boring adults? These are the type of films that kids are supposed to be rolling over laughing. I have sat with kids watching this, and they were utterly silent.

title: Better than the original
review:
This has now made it onto my list of favourite superhero movies - alongside Ant-Man, Iron Man, Big Hero 6. I'm amongst the minority who enjoyed this more than the original, and I personally think it's much better than the original.
I will not spoil you on the plot. Simply watch it. I hated it the first time I watched this, but the second time around, I was surprised to find how much I love this movie!
A very mysterious plot with plenty of twists and turns, great voice acting, the darkest, most violent, and most intense Disney-Pixar movie so far - and I enjoyed it for it's intensity and dark themes. Still cheesy, but definitely enjoyable. Engages you from the point it starts (unlike the first one), and sooo amazing, "Incredibles 2" is a recommended movie flick.

title: A Good Long-Awaited Sequel
review:
The Incredibles was a good Pixar film, and when I heard of this sequel, I was hyped. Picking up immediately where the first film ended, after being arrested battling the Underminer, with the destruction causing the Superhero Relocation Program being shut down, Mr. Incredible, Elastigirl, and Frozone are invited by Winston Deavor, a wealthy businessman who is a superhero fan, who wants the three's help to re-legalize Supers. Elastigirl is put in the front line first, as she is the least destructive, and Mr. Incredible becomes a stay-at-home dad, especially when Jack-Jack, the baby of the family, is developing his powers.

While I have heard complaints about feminist messages and such, but I don't care about political messages. Besides, Mr. Incredible is okay with it, as he tells Elastigirl to go and do the job Winston gave her so their kids (Violet, Dash, and Jack-Jack) can have the choice. Also, he does his best to be a good father while Elastigirl's away fighting crime, so basically, it's saying anyone can be anything, regardless of their gender.

The main cast from the first film returns, with the exception of Dash, who has been recast due the VA from the first movie hitting puberty. The new characters are awesome, and the story is good, with a huge twist to the villain I will not spoil. This is how a sequel is done, and is recommended.

title: Better than the first one
review:
I was initially worried that this wouldn't deliver what we were waiting for but it did and it's better than the first one. It begins where the first one left off where they prepare to fight The Underminer(John Ratzenberger). While doing so Violet's boyfriend accidentally discovers her identity and the main villain ends up escaping.

Things get worse when they find out the service that helps superhero's has been dissolved leaving them without any financial assistance. Things change when a fan of superhero's appear and offers Elastigirl a job while Mr. Incredible stays behind to take care of the kids.

Now you'd think this would be a rehash of the first but instead they go a different direction and show how Bob would handle it. The end result is a hilarious set of jokes involving the baby who's powers develop even further much to Bob's excitement/horror. There're also some emotional scenes such as when Violet finds out that Bob was behind her boyfriends memory being erased.

Meanwhile Helen enjoys her job and the perks that come with it such as the motorbike she's given. Man, any scene with her riding that bike is awesome because she contorts herself so much and it's just cool. Things however get strange when a villain known as the Screenslaver pops up and starts controlling the technology and superheroes. With little time Elastigirl needs all the help she can to stop this new villain.

The animation's faster, the dialogue's well written and characters are as likable as ever. The action scenes are very much improved. Jack-Jack pretty much steals the show. His fight scene with the raccoon is funny and cool. All in all it's a great movie! Check it out.

title: Decent sequel
review:
The Incredibles was a fun superhero comedy with a clever twist. The Incredibles 2 is a fun superhero comedy with a ... familiar twist. I guessed what was going on early on but thought, no, they can't possibly be just repeating the first movie. But yeah, they are.

While the movie is utterly predictable and not always entirely sensible (heroes near the end don't do a super-obvious thing because it would have ended the movie 20 minutes earlier), it still has some terrific moments, most of these involve the youngest Incredible. There's also some nice exploration of traditional gender roles.

I loved the original the first time I saw it but only liked it when I recently re-watched it. This felt a lot like watching the same movie a third time, which may be why I was less entranced yet again.

Not *great* Pixar, but still fun.

title: Beautiful Design But Not Quite As Good As The First
review:
The Nutcracker: The Fourth Realm and Incredibles 2 are hands down the most beautiful films I've seen this year as far as production and design. Though, both were a bit lacking in the story department. Incredibles 2 has a story, and it's fine, it just doesn't hold up quite to the original, which was fairly flawless. I was fine with the feminist spin some are on here raving like lunatics that it's some political agenda. Ha. Animated films take 3 years to make. And, unlike live-action films, the script and voice-over work has to be done ahead of time so directors can't take liberties like they do in live-action. Basically, the structure is much more rigid and planned out than the Marvel live-action films where the storyboard artists come up with the action scenes then they hire a writer to write around them, or the latest Mission Impossible, where the director was writing the film as he was filming it. So, it would be literally impossible for Pixar/Disney to infuse the current MeToo movement into this film as it had to have been written at least 4 or 5+ years ago. And unlike live-action, it would be extremely time consuming and ludicrously expensive to add new scenes later and edit them into an animated film. Not to mention, I've never ever heard of them doing that. And since that's what I do for a living I think I have fairly accurate understanding of how big studio animation works.

I love Brad Bird's work and having Elastigirl take the role of the superhero in this film seemed like an obvious transition. Mr. Incredible doing the same thing again would have been redundant, so, it was a good choice to have her take on that role. And I thought watching Mr. Incredible at home was funny watching a big clunky guy trying to maneuver home life and kids. Maybe seems cliche, but that is what animated physical humor is about and what the great Warner Bros. cartoons were built on. Like the whole scene with the Jack-Jack fighting the raccoon I could see they were going for that old school physical comedy that required no words. That was one of my favorite scenes. Great physical comedy. My favorite scenes involved the kids and I wish they would have showed more of Violet and Dash. I liked Violet's arc with Tony and it would have been nice to see that or her school life explored a little more.

While I like the ScreenSlaver villain, which was clever and a great pun, and I liked the Winston character and his enthusiasm, I felt that storyline was a little clunky. It started out good, and the whole PR angle with Elastigirl was great, and played into the first film with destruction being why superheroes were outlawed in the first place. I can't say I know what was wrong with it. Usually it's pretty clear to me but...I think what it is is that they tried to tackle a more adult subject in a kid's movie and then tried to maintain the animation, kid angle, which made it like two films, struggling to take spotlight. Understandable, Brad Bird is getting older and has been doing kid's films for a while and may be interested in expanding into more adult subjects. Which, once you're pegged into one genre it can be hard to break out. Like, the scene where she goes to SreenSlaver's hideout reminded me of serial killer shows. That seemed a bit adult for children. It was pretty tame, but I shouldn't be in a kid's film and thinking of Dexter. Though, the first Incredibles is a cartoon version of James Bond which is very adult, so, where do you draw the line? I did agree with some reviewers that the adults shouldn't be drinking whiskey in an animated kid's film. I don't remember the swearing...it was in E.T., if I remember correctly, but I do agree that adults should feel safe to take their 5-yr olds to a Disney/Pixar film and not have to worry about that.

As far as design I think it's the most beautiful post '70s animated film I've ever seen. Every visual department is on-point and should be proud of the work they've done. Not only was it visually more beautiful than the first Incredibles, but the best animated design I've seen since Sleeping Beauty. The backgrounds, props were amazing, layouts amazing, animation, flawless. The scene where it was darkly lit sitting around a beautiful blue pool, that was stunning. The story could have used more oomph to truly put it into one of my favorites. But it is definitely something I will look back to for design, as I think anyone in animation, visual effects, architecture, or design will, as it was truly inspiring.

title: Incredible!
review:
A pure successor of "The Incredibles".As like as the previous one this also has a great storyline which is the most important thing in such a movie like this.Loved the surprising abilities of "Jack jack":D
Really appreciate the works being done by disney studios.They are really improving day by day.

title: I mean , it was okay. Generic and formulated but okay
review:
Let me just preface this review by saying that I was never a massive fan of the first Incredibles. I think it's good and very unique. It does look very dated tho. So that's probably why I didn't love or dislike this movie.

This might be one of Pixar's most formulated movies. The film is ungodly predictable. The story is just not very engaging. The characters feel very ditached and don't feel like the same characters from the first film. Bob is very unlikable , Dash was annoying and Jack Jack was just a very unfunny comic relief. Helen and Violet are the only two that feel like the same characters and Frozon was pretty enjoyable.

The film does have good things about it. For example the animation is very well done. It isn't mind blowing especially comparing to there previous film Coco. The score I thought was well done but nothing great. The action was very well put together and the film did feel like there was passion put into it.

Overall it's a mixed bag. For every one positive there is an equally as big negative. I do understand why people like it and I do understand why people dislike it. As for me it's okay.

title: it does not disappoint
review:

MrIncredible- The law should be fair. What are we teaching our kids? Elastigirl- To respect the law. MrIncredible- Even when the law is disrepectful? title: Jack Jack is The Man
review:
This movie was GREAT!! Like TONY The Tiger (TM) "Grrrrreaaat!!" I loved it. My kids loved it and the time in the movie together was great (and it was even interrupted by a phone call to handle a work-related call that took 15 minutes). OMG, this movie was so much fun!

The plot was delicious and the "New" Protagonist of The Incredibles Family WAS AWESOME! I secretly wanted Elastic Girl to have her own movie in the sun but never wanted to remove her from her family...BUT this movie was everything I wanted in a sequel. Now, if we could just get this feel from the sequel to #BadBoys in #BadBoys4Life. Well, that's another story for another day.

I love the Family Angst, the teenager girl angst, the sibling angst and the Career Hero Angst. Ahhhh! Wonderful linear story from plot point to plot point. The story drove at a good solid pace to a great finale. What's the finale? The Incredibles 3: Jack Jack's Rescue.

Love the Governmental bureaucracy dealing with "The Supers" and the Elon Musk Advocate to help. Love the Antagonist! Did not see that coming! And the smidgen of the Disney Age of Ultron/Civil War nod? Excellent!

I say we stretch this family until #5! And let's let Elastic Girl get pregnant and bring another Super into the world riiiight after Jack Jack gets matures his powers.

#MustSee film of a wonderful Family Franchise! #GoDisneyGoDisneyGo! #GoPixarGoPixarGo! Thanks for listening and reading.

title: As good as the first one!
review:
Good sequel are quite rare, this movie is one of them!

Parents and children will enjoy a well written super hero story sequel which stands shoulder-to-shoulder with its predecessor with its impeccable blend of visual style, comedy, and family dynamics.

title: Really positive example
review:
"Incredibles 2" is the second part of the pixar "Incredibles" series. In this part, a rich businessman tries to legalize super-heros but is betrayed by one of his beloved ones, leading to a highly dangerous situation for the "Incredibles"-Family.

Personally, I haven't seen the first part of the series (shame on me), but I was positively surprised by this movie. It really came with a lot of heart and didn't just milk the cash cow like some other animated movies tend to do. The film mixes a kids-friendly superhero plot with some family issues that especially parents will know well. The only thing that really bothered me is that there are some logical difficulties, for example that kids could have turned the other superheroes way sooner if they took their glasses off when they had the chance to.

All in all this is an example of what an animated movie can achieve when it takes itself serious and doesn't just go after cheap gags or an uninspired plot that works well in cinemas. Both children and their parents will have their fun with this title.

title: Everything i thought it would be
review:

There were some scenes where i caught myself laughing so i guess i found it funny.

title: Pretty good
review:
Incredibles 2 was pretty good and more than worth the wait. I liked it almost as much as the original. The plot was good, a bit predictable, but not bad at all, as some people claim. I also like that they went with switched roles for the parents (working mom, stay-at-home dad), because it's the 21st century and if stay-at-home mom and a working dad is deemed normal, why couldn't the opposite work as well? Plus, both Mr. Incredible and Elastigirl still got to work as a team in fighting villains. The kids were cool too. Only the scene with Jack-Jack and raccoon wasn't funny, although I believe it was supposed to be? I don't know. It seemed like animal cruelty. Thankfully, nothing really happened, not to the baby and not to the raccoon.
I recommend watching.

title: More of the same
review:
After fourteen years, Brad Bird returns to his spy/superhero mix. The film picks up immediately after the events of the original film, which is admittedly something you don't see every day, but at the same time I also feel that it constrains the film, forces it into a cubicle.

The film looks and feels almost exactly like the original. Which is great. The colours are still phenomenal, the 60s spy thriller aesthetic is still superb and a refreshing change of pace, the characters feel familiar and the even though the special effects and animation quality have definitely gone up in fourteen years, the transition is pretty much seamless.

What I don't appreciate as much is the fact that this is almost exactly the same movie as the original one. At least in terms of theme, plot, character arc and underlying message. Once again we have superheroes under scrutiny. Once again Mr. Incredible has to juggle family duties with his consuming need of being a hero. And so on and so on, ad nauseam.

And certainly, a lot of sequels are very similar to their predecessors. But I think it's safe to say that we can expect more from Pixar. And more from Brad Bird. The man has reportedly said that he didn't want to make a sequel to The Incredibles unless he had something new to tell. Well... this isn't new. You can definitely watch it and appreciate it for its technical excellence, its great characters and its thrilling story. But you don't get anything from it. Nothing you haven't gotten from the original, that is. And I don't like that. This film universe has so much potential for great and meaningful stories that it's a great shame to see it wasted like this.

Still, it's by no means a bad film. It is enjoyable to watch and as a standalone film I do like it a lot. As a sequel it leaves much to be desired.

title: "Incredibles 2" upholds the Parrs as one of the best families in the history of cinema
review:
Luck or fate, my childhood, like those of thousands of human beings, was strongly influenced by Disney/Pixar's wonderful, sophisticated tales, which I saw on TV without any prejudice or criticism over and over again, movies that always were a healthy, high-quality entertainment. If I revisit these films today, I can possibly question certain aspects due to the passage of time and that's completely natural because a flick can be perceived in a myriad of ways according to age, mood or state of mind of the viewer. One thing that definitely seems to have been proven with unfading solidity is the thought that they're truly complex audiovisual works, these movies were the beginning of a kinetic digital era for animation genre that currently keeps going on both destroying box office expectations and exciting and teaching the new children with creativeness, passion, and effort. Although not all Disney-Pixar-made movies of the 21st century are modern classics, there are time-worthy pieces of art with visual tidiness and original, heartfelt storyline execution that keep alive- and many nonfans have complained about this - the 'Disney formula' that inspires hope, union, forgiveness and improvement.

That's why the first movie of the Parr family is so intimately untouchable for me, just like a few others beautiful animated films. Even with its unimportant flaws, it saved the 2000's superhero genre and set some rules to follow for the following animation stories thanks to one of the most powerful, meaningful, family-friendly screenplays in the industry, minimizing the margin of error as for the effect of the plot in worldwide audiences; this is one more Disney-Pixar feature-length for the ages.

A sequel was a high-risk move on the part of the company that produced major concerns among die-hard fans. On the one hand, for example, we have the Andrew Stanton-directed sequel/spin-off "Finding Dory" as a reference, but the Dory-centric movie was far from reaching the impact of Marlin's ocean trek. However, on the other hand, "Toy Story 2" by John Lasseter, former creative chief at Pixar and Disney, found the magic formula to enhance the good features from the first film and mix them with interesting, new improvements, turning into a truly computer-animated marvel. When it was announced that Brad Bird would direct this new story, things quieted down a bit, and after knowing the time between one film and the other - just 14 years!, - everyone breathed a sigh of relief. Today, it's possible to find out what kind of work was made along this time and, to tell the truth, the final cut manages to stand alone due to the return of the original vocal cast, the preservation of the 2000's animation style, a superhero family story with interesting repercussions and a few features that, although don't overshadow some detrimental decisions, at least, reach a good conclusion with a harmony of different genres not so miscible in that scenario.

"Incredibles 2" is an important film, a smart sequel that enriches its animated universe through a radically contrasting plot that refreshes the Hollywood-era animation, superhero scene. Even when we've seen movies driven by gender-swapped thematics between daughter and mother ("Freaky Friday"), criminal guy and mean girl ("The Hot Chick") or married man and single friend ("The Change-Up"), most of these body-life switches were, first of all, comedies, but also provoked by some kind of magic object or spell, as a fortune cookie, a pair of earrings or peeing in a sacred fountain. On this occasion, the same characters are who will switch roles by their own due to money crisis, survival compels them to make great efforts, just like a real-world family. Putting narcissistic, kind-of-sexist Bob Parr/Mr. Incredible in check when his wife takes on a fabulous new job is a risky plotting move that, even if it sounds clichÃ©, allows the story to argue that household chores and family issues aren't easy work or responsibility of a single member.

As for the family as a whole, the film gets a myriad of ways to use the comedy potential of every member with every-day, representative situations which take advantage of the well-defined personalities to set up hilarious sequences. Dash is, in some way, sidelined with humor focused on his lines this time. However, it puts a greater importance on Violet, who with her impossible-love sub-plot fit in with ease. But, no one can deny it; Jack-Jack steals the entire film by being one of the funniest, cutest characters this year. Math, breakups, dinner, household chores, and an adorable baby have never been better in an animated film.

Clearly, mom is the boss here; she gets the spotlight, a woman who's forced to lay aside her children and husband for an indefinite period to "make supers legal again." There is a strong, meaty commentary/fictional debate on the issue of the legalization of superheroes, a purpose going through several discussion-worthy obstacles. Helen, the new focal point in the plot, blissfully becomes one of the strongest rocks of this sequel because there are insufficient animated films that place a woman in the starring role with such priceless storyline skills. It's an important step in female representation in kids-oriented cinema to see not only how a woman monopolizes the whole story, but also the way they change the stereotyped conception of mother; likewise, just a few decisions feel synthetic as the story takes the right time for Bird's distinctive approach and development on the visual and narrative section, a balance where comedy takes place at home mainly, whereas the most dramatic events takes place among the streets of the huge metropolis. At a given time along the movie, Voyd, the Kristen Stewart-inspired character voiced by Sophia Bush, questions Elastigirl about how it she can level her life as a heroine, mom and wife, and although it's never answered by her, the film itself provides the answer.

While Mr. Parr does household chores, Elastigirl accepts to reintegrate in the field, just like that heroine dressed in red and white who kicked the asses of pickpockets and thieves some years ago. Brushing transient lawbreakers aside, the Screenslaver is her main target, a new-age antagonist that serves as a stark commentary on crowd control by media info day to day. This villain plays his role in an interesting way, at least until the predictable big twist takes place, from that moment on, the "bad guy" must recover strength from any situation in order to get back the threatening sense he was during the first fifty minutes.

Special mention for a couple of iconic characters who have the right to be part of the modern-day pop-culture as for animation field. That's right, it's the meanly charming Edna Mode, who, ironically, steals the show completely just as the first film with her upset, super-rich visionary costume designer thanks to the writers' witty work. But alongside Jack-Jack, who supports on his tiny shoulders the best visual gags, they're an explosive duo, in matters of comedy, of course. It will be no surprise that it's already insinuating their own movie, however, Disney has the things clear, and that makes us happy.

The animation isn't at the same level of detail as the most visually complex feats of the company, but it isn't by reason of a poorly-crafted work, is because the film sets just some minutes after the first feature film, that is to say, they decide to remain in the same timeline of 14 years ago, safeguarding its textures and animation styles, holding true to the simplicity of the features at that time, a world where realism doesn't have to be part of the equation. There are a few eye-popping landscapes; on the contrary, the film stays in urban settings to develop most of the plot. Truly unforgettable, beautiful sequences can be counted on the fingers of one hand, there are only a handful of important pictures, the best frame: An exhausted Bob going upstairs carrying his two boys in his arms, a visual poem that finds beauty in the emotional. It's understandable that Pixar doesn't deliver a visually arresting experience, but there is a character who went too far, id est, he looked like I was looking at a 2005 video game character, his expressions were made of rubber. It's Bob Odenkirk's character, Winston Deavor, he's of wax.

Leaving much to be desired with his "Fallen Kingdom" score, Michael Giacchino takes the throne back with the habitual power, experience in most of his soundtracks. A composer with more than 128 credits divided by video games, shorts and feature films, Giacchino creates again an excellent soundtrack for this animated sequel, one that is equally effective and exciting in both the most dazzling set-pieces and the simpler, dramatic scenes, there is passion in the melodies, which don't stay behind the pictures, they even got the spotlight in some set-pieces, modernized but faithful compositions. Another towering work of a towering composer.

"Incredibles 2" by Brad Bird is an unusual sequel, as it knows how to transmute into a Hollywood modern motion picture by using a mold that respects the universe built fourteen years ago. For a certainty, its greatest virtues are found in the priceless female importance, the skillful editing that balances comedy and drama as only Pixar can do, a super-absorbing soundtrack and an enchanting narrative treatment that simply would not be possible without Bird's experience, the numerous crew and the incredible vocal cast led by Craig T. Nelson, Holly Hunter, Samuel L. Jackson and Catherine Keener. Brimming with messages of representation, equality, family and topicality, this laugh-inducing family-friendly sequel is a step forward for animation and superhero genre, and another knockout for a company that honors its gems of yesteryear, that goes hand in hand with new technologies and its roots, that roots that were the awakening of a new era.

title: A rare sequel that is better than the original
review:
I've now seen this movie three times at the cinema. I don't usually bother putting in a review when there are already over 100 user reviews but since this is the best movie I've seen so far in 2018 I feel obliged to.

The Incredibles (a family of super heroes) live in a world where using super powers is illegal. They have to break the law to try to fix the law. In the first movie it was Mr Incredible that took the super spotlight but in the sequel it's Elastigirl. Mr Incredible is left at home minding the kids.

Rarely is a sequel better than the original. This is. Rarely is the movie funnier than the trailer. This is. Rarely does a movie maintain the gag count throughout. This does. Rarely does a comedy pack in loads of adventure. This does. Rarely does a movie have a brilliant twist at the end. This doesn't either but there are some surprises and four out of five isn't bad.

Everyone will like this movie. It's safe for all.

Add a point if animation or comedy-adventure is your bag. Subtract two points if you hate animation "cartoons" or think that super-hero movies are holy and should not be parodied.

review:
The voices are exactly as I remember, the story evolved as I hoped and I felt the movie was well executed. If the make a 3, I hope they don't take as long to make that as this! 
I think the animation was beautiful and the charactisation of their ages and the roles they play in their society and the time it is are very fun. The villain is a nice twist and I really enjoyed her reveal. Disney is becoming so open to new ideas and new ways to build characters, I think that this movie shouldn't have focused on its underminer roots in the trailer, as the underminer was there for 10 minutes max. I think that the way Bob and Helen are together, their way of life and how they care for each other are so much more deeper than some people can see and I think that they really captured what the scorned once-hero would feel like in Bob.
Especially the scene where Helen is talking about the train she saved, this was a throwback to the first movie where Bob couldn't save the train and to me it's little details like that that make it fun.

title: The Incredibles 2

title: A fantastic and topical sequel
review:
The Incredibles may be my favorite Pixar film, and I was very excited for the sequel to come out. I was not disappointed. The movie is remarkable in many aspects: the direction is better than ever, the soundtrack by Michael Giacchino is just as amazing as in the first one, the characters are still adorable and relatable.

As a child I was very curious about the "golden age" of superheroes that was briefly shown at the start of the original film, and since Elastigirl is a "remnant" of this golden age, it was incredibly satisfying to see her put in the center of the story.

But what's truly amazing is the antagonist : the Screenslaver (amazing name) uses screens to hypnotize people. This serves as a way for the writers to beautifully critisize the ubiquity of screens and what they are used for: regular media, social media and the entertainement industry.

The film makes it easy for young children to understand how the excessive presence of TV or the internet can affect judgement, imagination, and ultimately how any media today can lead to a false perception of reality, by allowing the cult of certain people, and by diverting people from their own community.

Even as an adult, I really liked the message that was sent, and how it was sent, thanks to the funny, multi-layered dialogue.

It's a shame that the last segment of the film is a lot wackier than the rest of the film, but it does not ruin the film, far from it. Overall it's a masterpiece.

title: Not up to original.

I loved the first film but found this one very boring. Undertone being pushed for healthy lifestyle , no bad thing, but the whole experience dragged out with action packed final last moments.

title: Don't let some negative reviews fool you
review:
It's a good movie. Not as good as the first one, of course, but it's still a good movie. I think that we all knew that there is no way that the sequel is gonna live up to the original, which only few movies accomplished. But that fact doesn't mean that the movie is bad or disappointing. I went to the theaters with my 8 year old cousin and we had a good time. There was a lot of good action and good humor. True, it didn't have as much character moments as the original one, but ones it had was more than enough.

Negative reviews say that "Disney turns everything into comedy". Most of the comedy in this movie comes from the baby, which was supposed to be comic relief, so i don't see what's the problem with it. All other main characters also had their funny moments, but not enough to turn them into blatant comic reliefs.

Plot isn't too complicated and it was easy to guess who was the villain. But still, even though not as good as Syndrome, it proved to be entertaining and dangerous foe.

Overall, if you don't expect this movie to be as good as the first one, you'll probably have a good time. Watch it for what it is: a sequel to one of the best animated movies ever.

I won't recommend this movie to those with epileptic problems, since there are few very flash scenes that might trigger attack.

title: Best Movie!
review: Incredibles 2 is amazing and 'totally wicked' film since their last film, Coco. Sure the sequel can have it's quirks like with a plot that copying elements from the first Incredibles, but with a great executed story (like the role reversal), animation that gonna a hugh upgrade from the first film, humor that is still funny as last time, great voice acting brought by the returning voice actors and the new ones and characters that are still memorable like before. This is great highly recommendation for both Pixar fans, super hero fans, Incredibles fans and ones who are a fans of Brad Bird who enjoy this like the first movie. I gave this 14-year long awaited sequel 9/10 for being the best Pixar sequel/film of 2018.

title: Some people are bashing this film for little or no reason
review:
I've just finished watching this movie with my 8 year-old son. Both he and I are huge fans of the first film, and I've been waiting 14 years for this sequel to come out.

The movie is good, not as good as the first, but it is enjoyable and a nice way to entertain the little ones if you've got them. If you grew up as a kid watching this movie, I'll tell you that you probably are not going to like this one.

Now, to clear up some of the negatives being bandied about by the other reviewers:

1) 'God' and 'Hell' are not curse words. Literally any word can be considered a curse word in the correct context i.e. "the reviewers of this movie are fudging puppy lovers with not an ounce of shooting sense between them" - no curse words right? Bt you've already understood the inference - don't bash a movie which uses two words that are not cuss words but you've gotten overly sensitive about - if you have a problem with the language, then be a responsible parent and tell your children not to say them - it's your personal opinion, keep it that way.

2) the use of drink in the movie - there are scenes where Elastigirl is at an ambassadorial function and is seen to be drinking a dark red or brown liquid from a glass - at no point is this explicitly stipulated to be alcoholic, except for a moment later on in the film where someone says "is it ok to drink on the job?" (when no job or official working capacity is technically being done).

Firstly, adults drink alcohol from time to time. Doing so responsibly is absolutely fine, we are not living in prohibition era America. Disney have done nothing wrong to have a character drink a drink (alcoholic or otherwise) within their movie. It would be a different story if the drinking was excessive, or resulted in drunken behaviour - but then again how many of you were up in arms about the scene in "The Good Dinosaur" where a child and a dinosaur ate some berries and went on a seemingly drug-induced 'trip'? How many of you are going to boycott the live-action Dumbo because in the animated original Dumbo gets drunk and sees pink elephants?

Once again here on IMDB, people are being way too sensitive and it gives the movie an unjust review scoring.

The story and the villains may be predictable to some, (personally I clocked it straight away as being one of two possible characters) but again, let's all step back a second and realise this is a kids movie, not a Christopher Nolan epic like 'Inception' or 'Interstellar' - the plot needs to be accessible enough for kids, and entertaining enough for adults - for over 25 years Pixar has been treading this line with aplomb, and now all of a sudden people are outraged because they dare to make a sequel which has female characters taking more of a lead, and they call this "Feminist propaganda" - wake up and grow up people - I'm a dude, and wouldn't call myself a feminist, but it's clear that this movie is obviously tackling some themes that are a hot topic, but in no way is this 'propaganda'.

Overall, the film is entertaining but nothing to shout about. It's nice to see Mr Incredible deal with his sidelining and become the parent that Mrs Incredible knows he can be, and it was a hoot to see Jack Jacks various powers taking some of the spotlight. It's never going to be the original film, but if that's all you want from this movie then here's a tip - go raid your DVD or Blu Ray collection and watch the first one again and give this a miss.

title: Great Sequel
review:
Great film for all with an interesting follow on from the 1st. However I suspect if you're the kind of person who believes that everyone should be armed and gun control is a liberal plot to destroy freedom, Barrack Obama is a Muslim, segregation wasn't all bad and women should be content to exist solely to serve men then you will hate this film However given that its already made a billion dollars and is likely to be one of the highest grossing films of the year your loss. Welcome to the 21st century.

Agree with others that it would have been great to have some of the super heroes involved that were mentioned in the first Incredibles but overall really good animation, excellent comedy scenes and a story that works on a number of levels

title: A fantastic sequel that is well worth the wait
review: The first incredibles film is one of my favourite films of all time and I can't believe we have had to wait 15 years for a sequel but we have finally been given it and if you are a fan of the first film you will enjoy this film, hopefully as much as I did. The premise of the film sees being a superhero made illegal, elastigirl is sent out to give supers a better outlook while Mr incredible is left to look after the kids. I think Craig T Nelson and Holly hunt are perfect as the roles of Mr incredible and elastigirl respectively, I love the reverse roles they are put in this film and how their characters deal with certain situations is just so fitting of their characters. The rest of the family are back and Jack jack steals the show in this film as he starts to discover his powers and it is just hilarious to watch. Dash and violet are fun in the roles given to them but they fade into the background at times in this film. Samuel l Jackson reprises his role as frozone and he isn't in this film as much as you want him to be but he is great when he is on screen. The villain though doesn't provide much intrigue to me and I feel like they weren't an important part of this film. The story is interesting and deals with some themes that are pretty mature and seemingly reacting to the huge explosion of superhero films in the media today. However, the biggest negative in this film is the plot twist involving the villain. I predicted the twist straight away and it didn't come across particularly well at all. The script has the likeable humour from the first film and some great drama that adds to the complexity of these heroes and there lifestyles. The style of the film has some great action set pieces involved that really grew in stature as the film progresses. Also this film moves quickly and flows really well to keep you interested throughout. Overall this is a fantastic sequel that is worthy of the wait and definitely worth a watch.

Right from the start I was entertained and for me that's why I watch movies, not for a deep meaning, just pure enjoyment and this one ticked all the boxes, awesome movie, good job.

title: Familiar but familial
review:
I adore The Incredibles. In fact, I'd say that of Pixar's early 2000s movies, it would be my favorite. Understandably, I was hyped for this movie when it was announced, to the point that I watched its prequel again in order to prepare myself for continuity errors here. After a bit of deliberation, my father managed to find a Friday evening that worked for both of us. Now that we have seen it, what is my personal opinion?

Admittedly, the already familiar plot does draw back on the potential of this movie as a sequel, since it pulls some of the same plot points from the first one but with drastic tweaks. Fundamentally, it's very similar to the first Incredibles, but when carried out, it's a tad more interesting than it would seem. It trades some of the originality and witty, insightful commentary for humor, which is actually a very acceptable trade-off. Sure, there are the clichÃ© jokes such as hand washing, but many of the others are fast-paced. I could actually recall most of my fellow audience members chuckling at some parts. Of course, we also have the family focus side, which is conceptually identical to the first movie but is twisted. Again, not original, but the edits are just enough to save it from being a retelling of the first movie. As time has drawn on, Pixar has continued to upgrade their films, and here, the aesthetics actually received some very glorious upgrades. The environments feel like more attention was added to the detail, and the effects take advantage of the 14-year gap with light flashes and real world tech like VR (the hypnotism goggles). As one of the first film's officers would say to Pixar regarding the overall animation, "You've done it again." I won't talk much about the main characters since they're the same, but I do admire the slight development of Jack-Jack and how the focus on the legal status of supers affects the returning characters. I was disappointed that we didn't see Mirage, Bomb Voyage, or some other characters from the original movie, but I do feel like the new supers and the Deavors made up for it in the end.

If you are a fan of the first Incredibles, you will either love this film for its action, humor, and improved animation, or hate it since, considering its similar plot to the prequel, it may as well have been a (n honestly well thought) fanfic of the first movie. For everyone else, this is more of an older kids' film due to its language and slightly more mature subject matter, but it still has the action, humor, and consistent commitment to family and life that should make it a solid bet for entertainment. I personally enjoyed it, and I expect that families will, most likely, end up satisfied.

title: what a sequel
review:
Wow is what i want to say, this reveiw may contain spoilers

the sequel to what i deem the best pixar film done so far, and the sequel didnt dissapoint

When the underminer rains havoc on the city the incredibles are there to save the day only to be penalised as supers as its still illegal.

The incredible family have to be relocated and are told to refrain from using their powers. However a company claiming they want to bring back supers send Elastagirl on a few missions to show the world why they need supers.

all the while mr incredible is battling the quest of being a dad of not 2 (spoilersssss)

but 3 super children, it turns out jack jack has about 17 different powers and bob is struggling to control and look after him,.

Meanwhile elastagirl is hunting down someone who can hipnotise people and make them commit crimes like the attempt to crash a train which Elastigirl foils.

Bob meanwhile takes Jack jack to see Etna who makes a suit for the baby which controls his powers so its easier for Bob.

It turns out the hiponotist has been under Elasticgirls nose the whole film, she ends up captured and hipnotised and Bob get a call to rescue her and he also gets hipnotised. Even Frozone is captured. There are multiple supers under the control of the hipnotist. So it comes down to the kids to save the day.

The kids prove they are just as super as their parents battling other supers and jack jack being the funny part of the film being stronger than any of the others.

Ultimatley they baddy gets beaten a group of supers stop a boat from crashing into a city and supers become legal again. I can see a 3rd coming at some point. Maybe a prequel or another sequel but the incredibles world has so much to offer. Disney need to take a look at these writers they use here and implement them on some of their other projects including star wars and marvel. This pips anything ive seen come from disney in ages.

Great film entertainment and fun for the whole family.

title: Definitely a must watch for all ages - but why did it take 14 years for nothing special?
review:
If you liked the first movie, you will like this as well - nothing less, nothing more. But this movie explores a few truths about the 'Incredible' family that was surprisingly invisible in the first movie.

A few pointers on the 'Incredibles' family:

*Mr. Incredible is a bigot and a chauvinist who has a hard time dealing with his wife's success.

*Mrs. Incredible could have definitely done better.

*Dash is a good looking boy who is surprisingly responsible for his age.

*Violet has the most annoying, whiny voice that makes you want to hurt yourself.

*Jack-Jack Parr (the baby) is the MVP of this movie and is responsible for almost all of the laughs and endearing moments this movie has to give.

Enjoy it as a one time fun family blast!!! - if you do watch this movie more than once and it is not for Jack-Jack, you better take a hard, good look at your life.

Cheers.
